tumors.clinicalInfo:
RAPIDLY PROGRESSIVE GN = CRESCENTIC GN.
Clinico (RPGN) - Pathologic (crescents > 50% of glomeruli) syndrome (morphologic pattern of several diseases):
(a) Immune-complex (IF: granular IgG) ≈30%: Post-infectious GN, SLE, MPGN, IgA/HSP (rare in each).
(b) Anti-GBM (IF: linear IgG) ≈10%: Anti-GBM nephritis (no lung) or Goodpasture syndrome (lung involvement, pulmonary hemorrhage).
Antigen is α3 chain of collagen IV.
May follow exposure to volatile hydrocarbons.
Treat with plasmapheresis + immunosuppression.
(c) Pauci-immune (IF negative) ≈60%: ~90% ANCA positive.
Idiopathic or systemic small vessel vasculitis (MPA, GPA, EGPA).
Morphology: crescents from proliferation of parietal epithelial cells + monocytes + fibrin; progressive sclerosis and glomerular obliteration.
EM: GBM ruptures → fibrin leaks to Bowman’s space → crescent.
Immune complexes dense in (a); none in (b),(c).

Ischemic or toxic AKI.
Muddy brown granular casts; mild proteinuria; FeNa often >2%.
Common settings: shock, sepsis, nephrotoxins (aminoglycosides, amphotericin, cisplatin, myo-/hemoglobin).
Complement normal.
Supportive care; remove insult.

Main drugs: (1) Antibiotics: β-lactams (penicillins, cephalosporins), sulfonamides, fluoroquinolones, antituberculous (isoniazid, rifampin).
(2) NSAIDs: may present with nephrotic-range proteinuria with MCD-like histology.
Less frequent: (3) Diuretics: thiazides, furosemide.
(4) Antiulcer: cimetidine, ranitidine, omeprazole.
Clinical: 1–3 weeks after exposure—fever, rash, eosinophilia, hematuria, sterile pyuria; up to 50% ARF in elderly.
Eosinophiluria helpful.
Usually reversible after withdrawal.
No dose relationship.
Recurs on re-exposure.
Pathology: interstitial edema and inflammation (± eosinophils, ± granulomas) with tubular injury/necrosis.

Children 2–8y; may follow viral infection or immunization.
Nephrotic syndrome with normal renal function, no hypertension, no hematuria.
>95% steroid response; excellent prognosis.
LM: normal; IF: negative; EM: diffuse podocyte foot-process effacement; no immune deposits.
Pathogenesis: T-cell–derived circulating factors injure podocytes; reduced/abnormal nephrin in congenital/rare cases.
Associations: Hodgkin lymphoma; NSAIDs; atopy.

Primary/idiopathic: acute full nephrotic syndrome like MCD.
Secondary/adaptive: not full nephrotic syndrome; due to hyperfiltration and hypertension (reflux nephropathy, advanced GN, massive obesity, unilateral renal agenesis, sickle cell).
Viral: HIV (often APOL1 risk) with collapsing FSGS.
Toxins/drugs: bisphosphonates, lithium, heroin.
Genetic: podocin, actinin; APOL1 in people of sub-Saharan ancestry.
Compared to MCD: more hematuria, hypertension, ↓GFR; less steroid response.
~50% ESRD at 10y in adults.
25–50% recurrence post-transplant (sometimes within days).
LM: focal, segmental sclerosis; interstitial fibrosis/tubular atrophy.
Collapsing variant aggressive.
IF: IgM and C3 in sclerotic areas (trapping).
EM: diffuse foot-process effacement in non-sclerotic areas; podocyte detachment from GBM.
Pathogenesis: podocyte injury by circulating factors in idiopathic form.

) 85% primary with anti-PLA2R; 15% secondary: SLE (V), infections (HBV, syphilis, malaria), drugs (captopril, gold, penicillamine, rare NSAIDs), tumors (lung/colon; rare).
Course: nephrotic syndrome; 1/3 progress, 1/3 remit, 1/3 persist.
LM: diffuse capillary wall thickening.
IF: granular IgG+C3.
EM: subepithelial deposits with intervening GBM spikes and domes.
Pathogenesis: in-situ subepithelial ICs to podocyte antigens (PLA2R, THSD7A).
Limited inflammation; C5b-9–mediated podocyte injury.

MPGN (mesangiocapillary) is a morphologic pattern.
Primary idiopathic in children; secondary in SLE (IV), HCV (often cryoglobulinemia), HBV, chronic liver disease.
LM: mesangial/endocapillary hypercellularity with lobulation; double contours (“tram-tracks”) from mesangial interposition.
Type I (immune-complex): subendothelial deposits; IF granular C3+IgG±C4/C1.
Type II (dense deposit disease): dense transformation of lamina densa; IF C3 and properdin only; alternative complement pathway.
Clinical: nephrotic ± nephritic; low serum C3 common.
Slow progression; ~50% CRF at 10y; high recurrence after transplant in type II.
C3 glomerulopathy lacks IgG with dominant C3.

Nephritic presentation during/after infection; low C3 with near-normal C4 typical.
Evaluate source (endocarditis, abscess; staphylococcal in adults).
IF often “starry sky” granular pattern; subepithelial “humps” on EM in poststreptococcal cases.

Skin purpura (leukocytoclastic vasculitis); abdominal pain and GI bleeding; arthralgia.
GN with recurrent hematuria/proteinuria for years.
Often follows respiratory infection.
Mostly children.
Serum IgA↑ in ~50%; IgA in dermal capillaries.
May represent systemic variant of IgA nephropathy.
LM: mesangial proliferative to focal/diffuse proliferative GN.
IF: mesangial IgA.
Generally good prognosis, but some progress to CRF.

Very common mesangial IgA GN.
Recurrent gross or microscopic hematuria in children/young adults (M:F ≈3:1).
Occurs during or shortly after viral URI/GI infection, in contrast to postinfectious GN (7–14 days later).
20–35% progress to CRF with risk factors: age, heavy proteinuria, crescents, sclerosis/fibrosis.
~40% recurrence in transplants but rarely leads to failure.
LM: mesangial proliferative to normal.
IF: mesangial IgA1 and C3 without C4/C1 (alternate pathway).
EM: mesangial deposits.
Pathogenesis: aberrantly glycosylated IgA1 from mucosa accumulates in mesangium, activates complement (alternate pathway).
Associations: celiac, liver disease.

Major cause of CKD and CV mortality.
Appears after 10–20y of diabetes; risk ↑ with poor glycemic control and hypertension.
Tight glycemic control and ACE inhibitors slow progression.
Pathogenesis: hyperglycemia → hyperfiltration and mesangial matrix expansion; nonenzymatic glycation (AGEs) → microangiopathy with GBM thickening.
LM: GBM thickening, mesangial matrix expansion, diffuse or nodular (Kimmelstiel–Wilson) glomerulosclerosis; afferent/efferent arteriolosclerosis.
Changes recur in kidney transplants unless pancreas transplanted.

Renal involvement in ~50% clinically; >95% by LM/IF/EM.
ISN/RPS classes I–VI.
III/IV: nephritic with hematuria/proteinuria, often crescents/necrosis; “wire loops” from massive subendothelial deposits; hematoxylin bodies rare.
V: membranous with nephrotic syndrome.
IF: “full house” IgG, IgA, IgM, C3, C1q.
EM: mesangial, subendothelial, and/or subepithelial deposits.
Tubuloreticular inclusions in endothelium.
Biopsy essential for classification and therapy.

Diffuse proliferative GN classically after group A β-hemolytic streptococcal infection; also after staph, sepsis, viruses, or during endocarditis.
Latency 1–4 weeks after pharyngitis/impetigo.
Children 5–10 most common.
Streptococcal antigens plant in glomeruli → in-situ ICs.
LM: large hypercellular glomeruli with endocapillary hypercellularity and leukocytes.
IF: granular IgG and C3.
EM: large subepithelial “humps” (ICs).
Clinical: smoky/cola hematuria, oliguria, edema, hypertension, RBC casts; ASO/anti-DNase B elevated; low C3.
Prognosis: >95% recover in children; adults worse; small risk of RPGN or chronicity.
